Soapwort: Sweet treat in small quantities but toxic in large quantities
3 Sisters-Squash: Edible once cooked, can eat squash blossoms
Iris, tall bearded: Taste disgusting and the bulbs are poisonous
Sugar Maple: Seeds can be removed from the samaras and eaten raw or roasted. The trees could be tapped and you can drink the sap straight from the tree or boil it down into maple syrup
Star Magnolia: Blossoms eaten pickled. Young leaves edible when cooked, but not desireable.
Bunchberry: Sweet, very dry and mealy, best dried like raisins
Fringe Tree: Fruit is edible when pickled, like an olive

Swamp Azalea (Clammy Azalea): Flowers are star shaped, fall color yellow orange and purple
Bronze Fennel: Interesting coloration. Blue green leaves with coppery-yellow flowers.
Soapwort: Showy flowers, generally small and pink
Common Strawberry: 3 green leaves, numerous white flowers mature to red fruit
Bunchberry: Berries are red, the plant resembles dogwood trees. Oval leaves dark green. flower consists of four oval petals. White flowers.
Fringe Tree: Fluffy white flowers appear on male trees. Females have less remarkable flowers. Tree leaves turn yellow in the fall. Female fruits are a dark blue in late summer. In the winter, the branches have an interesting configuration and the bark is smooth, gray, and rigid.

Swamp Azalea (Clammy Azalea): X- flowers are star shaped, fall color yellow orange and purple

Fringe Tree: The branches droop over to create a hiding space

Soapwort: Plentiful flowers can be used in flower crown, tiny seeds have potential as play parts
Iris, tall bearded: Seeds are of interesting shape, but are not plentiful. Would need a well established patch to make this worth it for play parts.
Windflower: Could be used for a flower crown
Fringe Tree: Flowers, fruit, large fallen leaves in autumn

Plant Name (Colloquial): Can be used to create Mazes/Labyrinths/Spirals [PRESENT]

Bronze Fennel: Interesting coloration. Blue green leaves with coppery-yellow flowers
3 Sisters-Squash: Native American planting technique, large leaves
Sugar Maple: Seeds spin as they fall to the ground
Bunchberry: Flowers have unique symmetrical configuration, the leaves are geometrically inclined as well.
Fringe Tree: The flowers are fluffy and unique
